bibl.title: Sir Robert Douglas's Baronetage of Scotland

div.p: In the Year of 1594, or 1595, the clan Macgregor, with some of their lawless neighbours, came down upon the low Country of Dunbartonshire, & comitted vast outrages & depradations, especially upon the territories of the Colquhouns. This Humphry raised his vassals & followers to oppose them, & was joined by many of the Gentlemen in the neighbourhood. Both parties met in Glen frune, where a bloody conflict ensued. They fought with incredible obstinacy till night parted them, & there were many brave men killed on both sides, but the highlanders appear to have had the better.

The Laird of Colquhoun made his escape from the field of battle, & retired to a strong castle of his own in that neighbourhood; but being closly pursued by a Party of the enemy, they broke into the castle, & found him in a vault* * at this mark on the Margin of the Book is noted (M.S. hist. of the family of Luss&ca)where they instantly put him to death with many instances of cruelty; and, he having no male-issue was suceeded by his Brother,
Alexander &c
N.B. The above is Article XIII Humphrey Colquhoun of that Ilk

div.p: Our Soveraigne Lord, and three Estates of this present Parliament, understanding &c. as the Original Act will shew herewith sent the Title page whereof is above recited.
K. William & Q. Mary's first Parliament Sep. IV. 15 June 1693.
XXXIX. Act. for the Justiciary in the Highlands.

Our Sovereign Lord & Lady, the King & Queen's Majesties, for the more effectual suppressing of the Depredations & Robberies so frequently committed in the Highlands, to the Prejudice & Ruins of many of their good Subjects & to the reproach of the Laws & Government of Parliament enact & declare, That their Majesties by virtue of their Prerogative Royal, may grant Commissions of Justiciary, one or more, & for such time as they shall think fit, for the Bounds of the Highlands, with all the Powers necessary and usual in such Commissions: and excepting therefore the Bounds and Lands lying & comprehended within the heretable Right of Justiciary General pertaining to the Earl of Argyle &c. –––––

And further, for the Ends foresaid, their Majesties, with advice and Consent foresaid, do hereby review the Act of Parliament 1633 against the Clangrigor, & that notwithstanding the same was rescinded in the year 1661. which Act rescissory, their Majesties hereby Annul and make void; and their Majesties considering, that the extending of Acts made anent Clans & their Chieftans, for the more effectual repressing of Thefts & depredations in the Highlands, may also be singularly usefull for preserving the publick peace: do therefore hereby extend the same to the ease of the publick peace, & for preserving thereof, as well as to the Thefts and Depredations.
N.B. I cannot find this rescissory Act Anno 1661, 2. Can it be a private one?

I was indeed at a Loss to know what Queries you desired solutions, till the receipt of your Card dated 11 Feby 1776 only came to hand this forenoon. I referr you to mine of yesterday & in reply to the Card you have the Extract from Robert Douglas's Baronetage p 25 which corresponds pretty much with yours p 385 Tour 1769 Quarto Edit:As Paton notes, the wording of Pennant's account of the Battle of Glen Fruin closely matches that of the extract from Douglas enclosed with this letter. See A tour in Scotland 1769 (3rd edn. 1774), Appendix VIII,pp.385-386: 'Of the Massacre of the Colquhouns'. With the greatest difficulty have got the Sheet of Sir Robts. Book relating to this Subject under the Clan Mc.grigor which accompanies this: have torn out the Act of Parliament 1633out of a Copy by me for your Satisfaction also, besides you have K.Will.m. & Q. Mary's Act on the same subject at least as much as relates to the point in hand: if the Sheet of the Magazine can be got that shall be sent this night, or tomorrow when I get abroad (having been confined somedays with a severe Cold) to get it from the Printer; I shall for the last time again apply to the Register if possible to get the Act of Council, all which by tomorrow's post: had this Card reached me sooner your request should have long 'ere now been complied with: having accidentally got a sight of the English News Papers it is there mentioned to be the Edinburgh Magazine Septr. last, wish it may be got here now as most of them are sent to Mr. John Murray Bookseller London, but shall try tomorrow for it. ––––– I beg you will not impute my Silence to your Queries on any other head than the not earlier receiving them than this day.

If you want to be further satisfied with Sir Robert Douglas's Book I beg you may cause inquire at Donaldson's Shops where it possibly may be got right altho' should fondly hope this would presently answer the Business. ––––– In case Mr. Low send me any of the M.SS. give me particular directions how it may be forwarded to yourself & that by Land as I will not trust it by Sea.

closer.salute:
I am Dear Sir
Your most obedt. Servt.
